tn.text: "keeps away from other people" (UDB)

This speaks of a person disagreeing with sound judgment as if "sound judgment" were a person he fought with. AT: "he disagrees with all sound judgment" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
"good judgment" or "wise choices"

tn.ref: A fool finds no pleasure in understanding, but only
tn.text: "A fool does not care about understanding, but only about" This means the fool considers "understanding" the opposite of pleasure. AT: "A fool detests understanding and only finds pleasure in" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])

tn.ref: but only in revealing what is in his own heart
tn.text: This means that the fool only finds pleasure in telling other people what he feels and desires in his heart. AT: "but only in telling others what is in his own heart" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: what is in his own heart
tn.text: The contents of a person's heart refers to the person's thoughts and feelings. AT: "what he thinks" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: contempt comes with him—along with shame and reproach
tn.text: Here "contempt," "shame," and "reproach" are spoken of as if they are people who accompany a wicked man. Possible meanings are 1) people show contempt towards the wicked man and cause him to feel shame and reproach. AT: "people feel contempt for him along with shame and reproach" or 2) the wicked man shows contempt for others and causes them to feel shame and reproach. AT: "he shows his contempt for other people and causes them to feel shame and reproach" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
These two words have similar meaning and are used together to emphasize the "shame" felt by either the wicked man or other people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: The words of a man's mouth are deep waters; ... the fountain of wisdom is a flowing stream
tn.text: These two lines are parallel and it is implied that the man in the first line is a wise man. AT: "The words of a wise man's mouth are deep waters; ... the fountain of wisdom is a flowing stream" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: The words of a man's mouth are deep waters
tn.text: This speaks of a wise man's words being profound as if they were profound and as deep as deep waters. AT: "The words of a man's mouth are as profound as deep waters" or "The words of a man's mouth are deep and profound" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here the man is referred to by his mouth to emphasize what he says. AT: "of a man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: the fountain of wisdom is a flowing stream
tn.text: This speaks of the source of wisdom being plentiful as if it were a gushing spring. The gushing of the spring is spoken of as if it were a flowing stream. AT: "the source of wisdom is as plentiful as the water of a gushing spring" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: It is not good to ... to the righteous person
tn.text: These phrases can be written in positive form. AT: "It is good to treat the wicked person as he deserves, and to be just to the righteous person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
Here the fool is referred to by his "lips" to emphasize what he says. AT: "what a fool says brings" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"cause"

This speaks of the fool saying things that cause people to want to beat him as if he were inviting them to beat him. AT: "his mouth makes people want to beat him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here what the fool says is referred to as his "mouth." AT: "what he says" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: A fool's mouth ... with his lips
tn.text: Both of these phrases refer to what a fool says. AT: "What a fool says ... by what he says" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"will ruin him"

This speaks of the man causing problems and trouble for himself as if he were trapping himself like a man traps an animal. AT: "he will cause problems for himself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: The words of a gossip are like delicious morsels
tn.text: This speaks of the words of a gossip being desirable to listen to as if they were delicious food to eat. AT: "The words of a gossip are desirable to listen to" or (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
This refers to what a gossiping person says. AT: "The words that a gossiping person speaks" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_possession]])
small bites of food

tn.ref: they go down into the inner parts of the body
tn.text: This speaks of the words of a gossip going into a person's mind and affecting his thoughts as if they were food that was going into his stomach. AT: "and they enter a person's mind and affect his thoughts" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: one who is slack in his work is a brother to the one who destroys
tn.text: This speaks of the one who is slack being similar to the one who destroys as if they were actually related. AT: "is closely related to" or "is very similar to" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"is lazy" or "is not interested"

tn.ref: the one who destroys the most
tn.text: "the one who destroys everything" (UDB) or "the one who is always destructive"

tn.ref: The name of Yahweh is a strong tower
tn.text: This speaks of Yahweh protecting his people as if he were a strong tower in which they could take refuge. AT: "Yahweh protects like a strong tower" or "Yahweh protects his people like a strong tower" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here Yahweh is referred to by his name. AT: "Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This refers to righteous people. AT: "those who are righteous" or "righteous people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])

tn.ref: runs into it and is safe
tn.text: This speaks of people seeking safety from Yahweh and Yahweh protecting them as if he were a strong tower that they ran into for safety. AT: "run to him and they are safe" or "seek him and they are safe" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: The wealth of the rich is his fortified city
tn.text: This speaks of a rich person depending on his wealth as if his wealth were a fortified wall that protects him. AT: "The wealthy person depends on his wealth as a city depends on its fortified wall" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This refers to people who are rich. AT: "the rich person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
a city with strong defenses like walls and towers

tn.ref: in his imagination it is like a high wall
tn.text: This speaks of the rich person believing his wealth will keep him safe like a high wall keeps those inside a city safe. AT: "he thinks it protects him as well as a high wall" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: Before his downfall a person's heart is proud
tn.text: "First a person's heart is proud, but then comes his downfall"
This refers to a significant decline in a person's reputation or health.
Here a person is referred to by his heart to emphasize his thoughts and feelings. AT: "a person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

The word "humility" may be expressed as an adjective and the word "honor" may be expressed as a verb. AT: "a person must be humble before he can be honored" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: it is his folly and shame
tn.text: The word "folly" may be expressed as an adjective and the word "shame" may be expressed as a verb. AT: "it is foolish of him, and he should be ashamed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: A person's spirit will survive sickness
tn.text: Here a person is referred to by his spirit to emphasize his attitude. AT: "A person who is hopeful will survive sickness" or "If a person is full of hope in his inner being, he will survive being sick" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: but a broken spirit who can bear it?
tn.text: This is a rhetorical question, expecting the answer that few can bear it. This can be written as a statement. AT: "but it is very hard to bear a broken spirit." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This refers to being depressed. AT: "being depressed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: The heart of the intelligent acquires
tn.text: Here the intelligent person is referred to by his heart to emphasize his desires. AT: "The intelligent desire to acquire" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This refers to people who are intelligent. AT: "those who are intelligent" or "intelligent people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
"gains" or "obtains"

tn.ref: the hearing of the wise seeks it out
tn.text: Here the wise person is referred to by his hearing to emphasize what he desires to listen to. AT: "the wise seeks to learn about it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This refers to people who are wise. AT: "those who are wise" or "wise people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
Here the word "it" refers to "knowledge"
Here to "open the way" means to create an opportunity. AT: "may create an opportunity for him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means to be allowed to see someone. AT: "let him meet" or "let him be introduced to" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"The 1st." This refers to the first person to do something. AT: "The first person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
"Casting lots"

This refers to people who are fighting harshly over a dispute. When they are separated, they are no longer fighting over their dispute. AT: "and causes opponents to stop fighting over their dispute" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: An offended brother is harder to be won than a strong city
tn.text: This speaks of the difficulty of making peace with a brother you have offended by comparing it to the difficulty of winning a war against a strong city. AT: "If you offend your brother, finding a way to have peace with him again may be harder than waging a battle to win a city" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: quarreling is like the bars of a castle
tn.text: This speaks of the difficulty of resolving quarreling by comparing it to the difficulty of breaking down the bars of a castle. AT: "resolving quarreling is as difficult as breaking down the bars of a castle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
a fortified palace

tn.ref: From the fruit of his mouth one's stomach is filled; with the harvest of his lips he is satisfied
tn.text: These two lines have the same meaning and are used together to emphasize what is said. They can be combined. AT: "A person is satisfied by the results of the good things that he says" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This speaks of the good things that a person says as if they were fruit that came from his mouth. AT: "his wise speech" or "his good words" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

This speaks of a person being satisfied or content by the result of what they have said as if they had eaten and become satisfied" AT: "a person is satisfied" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This speaks of the good things that a person says as if they were fruit that is harvested. AT: "his wise speech" or "his good words" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"he is pleased"

tn.ref: Death and life are controlled by the tongue
tn.text: This can be written in active form. AT: "The tongue can lead to life of death" or "What people say can lead to life or death" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: by the tongue ... love the tongue
tn.text: Here the "tongue" refers to speech. AT: "by what people say ... love speaking" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

This speaks of a person receiving the consequence for what he says as if the consequences were fruit that he receives. AT: "will receive its consequences" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: many friends is brought to ruin by them
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "many friends--they will bring him to ruin" or "many friends--his friends will destroy him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"is more faithful than" or "stays more loyal than"
